awd_titl_txt: Developing an In-situ Sensor for Continuous Measurements of Total CO2 on Mobile Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
The PIs request funding to develop, groundtruth, and deploy an in-situ sensor for continuous seawater DIC measurements on mobile observing platforms. The system will be capable of continuous, submersible measurements in-situ up to a depth of 3000m in the ocean. It will be designed and built primarily for deployment on AUVs and CTD-Rosette packages where fast response sensors are preferred. Because of the micro-flow characteristic, the sensor will have low power and reagent consumption tailored to the size and power requirements for underwater vehicles. The proposed sensor will be capable of measuring DIC accurately with high-resolution on mobile platforms. With nominal calibrations and testing, the new sensor will also be able to make continuous measurements of seawater pCO2 using a similar method.

Broader Impacts:     

The proposed work will promote teaching through the supervision of one female doctoral student and the training of at least one summer student through an educational program targeted for underrepresented groups in science. The development of a fast-response in-situ DIC sensor is certainly of interest for a broader community, and there is potentially a large enough market for the commercialization of this sensor. This instrumentation has the potential to provide high-resolution total CO2 measurements for several ocean research fields, ranging from ocean acidification to climate change. The sensor is proposed to be deployed in Buzzard Bay, MA in cooperation with the Buzzards Bay Coalition. The technology will be presented through the "Science Made Public" summer series.

Project Title: Developing an In-situ Sensor for Continuous Measurements of Total CO2 on Mobile Platforms

NSF Program and Award No: NSF OTIC Program, OCE 1233654

Program Officer: Kandace S. Binkley

PI: Zhaohui Aleck Wang

Awardee: Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution

Development of in-situ sensor technologies for measurements of seawater CO2 parameters has been widely recognized as a research priority in the carbon and ocean acidification research community. Of the four primary CO2 parameters -- partial pressure of CO2 (pCO2), total dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC), pH, and total alkalinity -- the technologies for in-situ sensing of pCO2 and pH are relatively mature and these two measurements can be used to define the marine CO2 system through thermodynamic calculations. However, such calculations may bear large, unacceptable errors in defining the CO2 system. There is an increasing demand for development of in-situ DIC sensors as the CO2 system can be more accurately defined through calculations involving DIC. Furthermore, there is a great need for fast-response DIC sensors to achieve high-frequency measurements required for deployment on mobile platforms, such as profilers, Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs), and Remotely Operated Vehicles (ROVs). The goal of this project is to develop an in-situ DIC sensor for high-frequency seawater measurements based on an improved flow-through spectrophotometric method.

As a major intellectual merit and outcome, this project has achieved its major goal, i.e., successfully developed and test-deployed a new fast-response, in-situ DIC sensor, CHANnelized Optical System II (CHANOS II). CHANOS II has been tested in situ on various deployment platforms from surface to ~1500 m water depth in the ocean so far. The collected in-situ data have shown that the sensor can achieve high precision and high accuracy measurements (~5 micromol/kg). It is capable of high-frequency (up to 1 Hz) in-situ DIC measurements with versatile deployment modes on both mobile and stationary platforms, which included so far CTD Rosette profiling, time-series monitoring, shipboard flow-through measurements, underwater towing, and ROV mapping.

The major outcomes of this project include:

(1) The development of the prototype CHANOS sensor has been published first by Wang et al. (2015). (2) The prototype CHANOS has been used to measure DIC in coastal salt marshes over tidal cycles and seasons to evaluate DIC export fluxes from salt marshes (Chu et al., 2018). It provides high-resolution DIC measurements in tidal marsh environments for the first time, and the results have vastly improved the assessment of lateral DIC exports from salt marches by capturing the true variability of the DIC export over tidal to seasonal scales. (3) The marsh data collected has been published on BCO-DMO, a NSF-supported data depository (https://www.bco-dmo.org/dataset/768607). (4) One patent has been approved, which paves the road for technology transfer and commercialization. (5) Three more peer-reviewed papers are being prepared for the latest deployments of CHANOS II in coastal waters. The 1st paper will describe the development and tests of the CHANOS II sensor, demonstrating its versatile, in situ capability. The 2nd paper will describe the high-frequency (up to 1 Hz) profiling deployments on a ROV in deep coral reef environments off the west Florida shelf conducted in 2019, which for the first time captured the in-situ, sub-mesoscale spatial variability of the carbonate system over deep coral reef communities. This study is valuable in examining how these deep communities experience and adapt high variability in their living environments, which may shine a light on the impacts of climate change, including ocean acidification, on these deep ecosystems. The 3rd paper will use recent CHANOS II data to analyze the carbon dynamics of various end-members in Waquoit Bay, MA, with the aim to assess the fate of lateral (tidal) DIC export from tidal salt marshes. (6) A series of seminars and conference papers have been presented using the data collected via the CHANOS system.

Two doctoral students have been trained in the sensor development during the course of the project. Because of the interdisciplinary nature of the project, the two students have learned both ocean engineering and marine chemistry. This greatly fostered training of next generation of interdisciplinary marine scientists, who understand technology development and are the first to use new technology to study the ocean in an unprecedented high-resolution. Both students have featured their CHANOS?s research in several WHOI and MIT news articles. One postdoc, another PhD student, two undergraduate interns, five engineers, and at least three research assistants have also been involved in CHANOS development, testing, and deployment, with positive impacts on their education and careers.
